page.title: 03HAVRA
page.content: HAVRA IS AN ISLAND ABOUT ONE AND A HALF KILOMETRES SOUTH OF BURRA. IT TAKES ABOUT HALF AN HOUR IN A BOAT TO GET THERE. IT IS UNINHABITED EXCEPT WHEN BURRA CROFTERS GO FOR LAMBING OR TO LOOK AFTER THE SHEEP AT OTHER TIMES. THE LAST PEOPLE TO LIVE THERE FULL TIME LEFT IN MAY 1923. THERE WERE ABOUT SIX HOUSES AND A SCHOOL. THERE WAS NO ELECTRICITY AND WATER CAME FROM THE WELL.THERE ARE STILL THE REMAINS OF THE HOUSES AND A WINDMILL. FOUR FAMILIES SHARE THE CROFTING RIGHTS TO THE ISLAND AND KEEP ONE HOUSE IN GOOD CONDITION. ALL ARE DIRECT DESCENDANTS OF THE WILLIAMSON AND JAMIESON FAMILIES OF HAVRA. CATS WERE PUT ON THE ISLAND TO GET RID OF THE RABBITS AND NOW THERE ARE NO RATS OR MICE OR RABBITS. ON A FINE DAY IN THE SUMMER PICNICS ARE POPULAR HERE.
